I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
equity investment of up to CNY162.5 million1 in the Sino-Green Climate Investment Fund (SCIF) 
in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1. 
 
II.  THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 
A.  Investment Identification and Description 
2.  The SCIF was recommended to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) by the PRC’s 
National Development and Reform Commission in support of their dual goals of mobilizing 
private sector finance to combat climate change and developing the PRC’s onshore private 
equity  fund  market.  The  fund  seeks  to  promote  resource  conservation  and  environmental 
protection by investing in companies and projects2 in sectors related to climate change in the 
PRC, and to provide fund investors with stable, long-term capital gains. The targeted fund size 
will be CNY1,300 million, with a first closing of about CNY650 million. The second and final 
closing will occur 1 year after the first closing.  
 
3.  The fund will be established in Tianjin Municipality as a foreign-invested venture capital 
investment  enterprise  (FIVCE).  It  will  be  managed  by  the  Tianjin  New  Cleansource  Fund 
Management Company (the fund manager, the same legal entity as the sponsor).  
 
4.  Onshore private equity fund. The SCIF will be one of the earliest onshore private 
equity funds exclusively targeting sectors related to climate change in the PRC, and ADB’s first 
investment  in  a  CNY  fund.  Onshore  private  equity  funds  provide  the  critical  function  of 
channeling domestic savings into productive investments. Through its investment in the SCIF, 
ADB will help to introduce international best practices and set high governance and safeguard 
standards  in  this  nascent  industry.  The  success  of  the  SCIF  will  demonstrate  a  practical 
modality  for  mobilizing  and  integrating  international  and  domestic  financial  resources  and 
intellectual capital to promote investment in climate change related businesses and projects. 
 
B.  Business Overview and Strategy 
5.  The PRC is one of the largest energy consuming and greenhouse gas (GHG) emitting 
countries in the world. Its status as such has led to increasing concern about energy security 
and growing public demand for reducing energy costs and addressing climate change in the 
country. This in turn has resulted in a convergence of social, political, economic, environmental, 
and  entrepreneurial  forces  that  is  collectively  driving  the  creation  of  vast  opportunities  for 
businesses to benefit as early movers in climate change and environmental technologies and to 
capitalize on the substantial policy support that exists in the PRC for the country to transition to 
low-carbon  and  climate-resilient  growth.  Equity  investment  is  in  high  demand  to  finance 
sustainable growth of those companies focusing on improving energy efficiency, developing 
renewable energy, conserving resources, abating pollution, and reducing carbon dioxide (CO ) 
2
and other GHG emissions.    
 
6.  Investment  strategy  and  selection  criteria.  The  fund  is  well  positioned  to  take 
advantage of the investment opportunities being created in sectors related to climate change. 
                                                
1 CNY financing funded from the ADB’s offshore CNY bond proceeds. 
2 Investments in projects will be limited to a maximum of 10% of the fund’s total committed capital.

2 
 
The  SCIF  will  primarily  invest  in  companies  at  the  expansion  stage  in  energy  efficiency, 
renewable  energy,  resource  recycling  and  conservation,  and  environment  protection.  The 
SCIF’s portfolio companies are expected to have (i) attained preliminary success in technology 
or commercial operations; (ii) exhibited strong business fundamentals and sustainable growth 
trends;  (iii)  committed  to  fully  meet  domestic  environmental  and  social  regulations  and 
requirements, and to comply with all applicable safeguard and social policies of ADB as well as 
the  anti-money  laundering  and  know-your-client  requirements;  and  (iv)  agreed  on  a  clear 
business development strategy and exit path with the fund manager. 
 
C.  Ownership, Management, and Governance 
1.  Ownership 
7.  SCIF has two anchor investors in the first closing, ZTE Energy (ZEN) and Bank of China 
Group Investment Limited (BOCGI). ZEN was established in 2007 in Beijing with registered 
capital of CNY1.29 billion. It makes direct and controlling investments in projects designed to 
produce  renewable  energy,  enhance  energy  productivity  through  energy  management 
contracting services, and protect the environment. BOCGI was incorporated in Hong Kong, 
China  in  1984,  and  is  a  wholly  owned  subsidiary  of  the  Bank  of  China.  It  is  a  leading 
professional investment management company and a pioneer private equity investor in the 
greater  PRC  region.  During  the  past  26  years,  BOCGI  has  invested  in  numerous  large 
infrastructure projects in Hong Kong, China; Macau, China; mainland PRC; and overseas.  
2.  Management 
8.  The  fund  manager  will  be  responsible  for  originating,  structuring,  and  negotiating 
transactions;  making  recommendations  to  the  investment  committee  with  regard  to  the 
acquisition  and  disposition  of  portfolio  investments;  monitoring  portfolio  investments;  and 
assisting  in  the  administration  of  capital  calls  and  distributions  to  investors,  and  investor 
reporting.  
 
3.  Governance Structure 
9.  Corporate  governance.  The  fund  will  establish  an  advisory  board  consisting  of 
representatives from each significant investors including ADB. 
10.  A dedicated and independent custodian account will be set up with a creditworthy local 
bank to handle cash transactions and asset trusteeship for the SCIF to ensure fund security and 
transparency.  
 
11.  Investment process. The fund’s investment process will comprise six cascading steps: 
(i)  project  initiation,  (ii)  preliminary  due  diligence,  (iii)  comprehensive  due  diligence  and 
evaluation,  (iv)  investment decision-making  and  operations, (v)  value-addition  services  and 
performance monitoring, and (vi) divestment. To achieve the strategic goals of the SCIF, the 
fund manager will adopt international best practices to screen, structure, analyze, execute, and 
monitor the SCIF’s investments. The fund manager will regularly conduct comprehensive sector, 
market, and policy analyses to support smooth and effective fund operations. A high priority will 
be  placed  on  risk  identification  and  mitigation,  and  on  balancing  risks  against  anticipated 
returns.   
 
12.  Investment committee. The fund will establish an investment committee consisting of 
five members. The investment committee will be responsible for updating the SCIF’s investment 
strategies, priorities, policies, and its investment management systems, covering information

3 
collection  and  analysis, financial  valuation,  risk  identification  and  control,  and  performance 
monitoring  and  evaluation.  The  investment  committee  will  review  and  make  decisions  on 
investment and divestment proposals in accordance with the SCIF policies and procedures.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
A.  The Assistance 
 
13.  It is proposed that ADB make an equity investment of up to CNY162.5 million in the 
SCIF, not exceeding 25% of the total commitments to the SCIF and not resulting in ADB being 
the single largest investor in the SCIF. 
 
B.  Expected Returns  
 
(The information in this section is withheld based on exception 9 in paragraph 126 of the PCP.) 
 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Exit Strategy  
(The information in this section is withheld based on exception 9 in paragraph 126 of the PCP.) 
 
2.  Reporting Arrangements   
  
14.  ADB will review all the SCIF reports on an ongoing basis, along with information on 
portfolio valuation and performance of individual portfolio companies. ADB will hold a seat on 
the SCIF’s advisory board and will be involved in discussions and decisions related to corporate 
governance, adjustment of investment strategies, and conflicts of interest.  
 
15.  The SCIF will retain a reputable accounting firm to conduct annual audits of its financial 
status and provide investors with four unaudited quarterly reports and one audited annual 
financial report. The fund will also submit an annual report on its environmental and social 
performance. 
 
D.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
16.  Catalyzing  resource  mobilization  for  climate  change  investments.  ADB’s 
investment in one of the first onshore private equity funds targeting sectors related to climate 
change will help to increase low-carbon financing in the PRC by demonstrating practical ways to 
achieve  a  decent  risk–return  balance.  The  associated  financing  activities  of  the  portfolio 
companies, such as long-term debt borrowing, corporate bond issuing, mergers and acquisition, 
carbon credit trading, risk insuring and guaranteeing, currency exchanging and hedging, asset 
restructuring, and initial public offerings, will contribute to broaden and deepen the capital 
markets in the region.  
    
17.  Introducing  international  best  practice.  ADB’s  involvement  in  the  design, 
establishment, and operations of the SCIF will ensure that the SCIF and its portfolio companies 
comply with the highest standard of governance and social and environmental safeguards. 
Good  governance  will  increase  investor  protection  and  inspire  investor  confidence.  High 
safeguard standards will mitigate the risks of any possible social and environmental damages

4 
 
and ultimately benefit both the SCIF and its investees. By introducing international best practice 
to the SCIF, ADB’s investment will have wider demonstration effects on the nascent industry of 
onshore private equity in the PRC.3

IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
A.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
1.  Impact 
18.  ADB’s investment in and assistance to the proposed climate change private equity fund 
can deliver a significant development impact as summarized in the design and monitoring 
framework. Over the long run, the ADB investment will help reduce GHG emissions, mitigate 
climate change effects, and enhance national energy efficiency, diversity and security through (i) 
mobilizing  and  utilizing  market  instruments  and  mechanisms  to  leverage  more  financial 
resources and technical support to expedite growth of companies concentrating on climate 
change businesses; (ii) facilitating private equity market development with a focus on clean 
energy  and  environmental  protection  industries;  (iii)  stimulating  financial  and  engineering 
innovations  to  improve  energy  efficiency,  develop  renewable  energy,  conserve  natural 
resources, and protect the environment; and (iv) generating demonstration effects in both areas 
of clean technology deployment and private equity fund operations. Since the poor are most 
vulnerable to energy insecurity and the adverse effects of climate change in terms of direct and 
induced damages on their productivity, income opportunities, and health, this investment will 
contribute in reducing poverty and spurring environmentally friendly socioeconomic growth.   
 
2.  Outcome 
19.  The outcome of ADB’s investment will be mainly reflected in the increased flows of 
funding and expertise mobilized to support sustainable growth of companies and projects in 
sectors related to climate change in the PRC. It will help demonstrate that it is viable for private 
equity funds to invest profitably in climate change companies and projects that will generate 
positive environmental and social externalities while harvesting decent financial returns. Most of 
the SCIF’s portfolio companies will adopt international standards for financial reporting and 
corporate governance that are necessary for initial public offering in a regional stock market.  
 
3.  Outputs  
20.  The key outputs of the proposed ADB investment will be the establishment of the SCIF 
for the purpose of supporting companies and projects in sectors related to climate change in the 
PRC.  The  governance  structure,  decision  making  procedures,  environmental  and  social 
management system (ESMS), and risk management systems of the SCIF shall meet ADB’s 
requirements. The fund manager will identify, screen, and evaluate investment opportunities 
and provide ongoing management advice and value-addition services to the SCIF’s portfolio 
companies.

B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  
1.  Consistency with Strategy 2020 and Country Strategy 
21.  The  investment  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  fundamental  goals  of  promoting  inclusive 
economic growth in an efficient, equitable, and sustainable manner and eliminating poverty in 
Asia and the Pacific. In Strategy 2020,4 ADB has designated energy and financial market 
development as two core operational sectors; and achieving environmental sustainability as one 
of  three  strategic  priorities,  aiming  at  (i)  mitigating  climate  change  through  facilitating  the 
transition  of  its  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  toward  low-carbon  economies;  and 
(ii) achieving  regional  energy  security  and  diversity  through  adopting  clean  technologies, 
improving  energy  efficiency,  and  scaling  up  clean  energy  development.  Recognizing  the 
importance of the private sector in realizing these objectives, Strategy 2020 has also highlighted 
the greater roles of the private sector in this endeavor.   
 
22.  ADB’s country partnership strategy,5 2008–2010 and country operations business plan,6 
2011–2013 for the PRC have emphasized balanced and sustainable growth with more efficient 
uses of resources and more stringent protection of the environment. The investment supports 
implementation  of  the  PRC’s  12th  Five-Year  Plan,  2011–2015,  which  highlights  resource 
conservation  and  environmental  protection  and  attaches  top  priority  to  improving  energy 
efficiency, reducing pollution emissions, and developing cleaner and renewable energy, while 
specifically requiring that financial assistance from international financial institutions be used for 
resource conservation, environmental protection, and infrastructure development. 
   
2.  Consistency with Sector Strategy and Relevant ADB Operations 
23.  ADB’s Energy Policy7 of 2009 reiterates the essential roles of the private sector in 
improving access to affordable and reliable energy sources and in securing energy market 
efficiency  and  competitiveness  in  the  region.  It  encourages  more  proactive  private  sector 
participation and public–private partnership to increase investable resources and to transfer 
cleaner technologies to the energy sector in ADB’s DMCs. ADB has committed to double its 
investments in clean energy projects to $2 billion per year by 2013. ADB’s Environment Policy 
(2002) has similarly corroborated the needs for reinforcing poverty alleviation, mainstreaming 
environmental protection, and strengthening partnerships with relevant stakeholders including 
private sector entities. ADB’s realigned strategic agenda on fighting climate change8 states that 
ADB  will  move  upstream  in  the  technology  development  process,  collaborating  with 
governments, venture and private equity funds, and other partners to facilitate transferring and 
deploying clean energy technologies. The investment is clearly aligned with ADB’s energy, 
environment, and climate change policies. 
 
3.  Lessons from Previous Operations 
24.  ADB has been working for nearly a decade to promote climate change financing and to 
support private equity market development in ADB’s DMCs. The lesson drawn from previous

investments is that incubating funds takes time and effort. As a result, ADB should focus on 
selecting those fund managers that are most likely to succeed in fundraising and investment, 
but may fall short without ADB. Relatively few private equity funds focus on climate change 
businesses in ADB’s DMCs, and it is much rarer in the case of onshore funds. When ADB 
intends to develop a new asset class, where few managers exist and ADB does not have the 
luxury to choose among established managers, it is appropriate for ADB to work with a first-time 
fund manager. Nevertheless, a great deal of time and effort is needed to ensure the proper 
setup, successful fundraising, and prudent investments of a first-time fund. ADB’s consistent 
commitment and support will be critical to the ultimate success of the new asset class it seeks to 
promote.   
 
25.  Another  lesson  learned  is  that  it  would  be  useful  to  supplement  strong  legal 
documentation  with  capacity  building  to  ensure  that  all  investee  funds  meet  ADB’s 
environmental and social safeguard requirements. ADB’s legal documentation makes submitting 
a compliant ESMS a condition precedent for drawdown. ADB is also implementing technical 
assistance9 to provide ESMS training to investee funds that have not submitted a compliant 
ESMS to ADB. These measures ensure that the investee funds have both the incentive and 
capacity to meet ADB’s safeguard requirements.  
 
V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
A.  Environment and Social Safeguards   
26.  ADB’s investment in the SCIF has been classified category FI (financial intermediary) 
under  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009).  The  SCIF  will  be  required  to  establish, 
maintain, and implement an appropriate ESMS to ensure that the SCIF’s investments are in 
compliance with applicable national laws and regulations and ADB’s requirement prescribed in 
the  Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  The  SCIF  will  also  be  required  to  comply  with  the 
implementation of ADB’s prohibited investment activities list. ADB will coordinate with fund 
manager to ensure that the ESMS is adopted prior to disbursement for the first investment, and 
guide the fund manager in environmental and social safeguards due diligence, monitoring, and 
reporting10.  
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy  
27.  The fund manager was advised of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to 
date) and Policy relating to the Combating of Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism 
(2003). Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and transparency, 
ADB will require the fund manager to institute, maintain, and comply with internal procedures 
and  controls  following  international  best  practice  standards  for  the  purpose  of  preventing 
corruption or money laundering activities or the financing of terrorism and covenant with ADB to 
refrain from engaging in such activities. ADB will ensure that the investment documentation 
includes  appropriate  anticorruption  provisions  and  remedies  for  ADB  in  the  event  of 
noncompliance. The investment documentation between ADB and the fund will further allow 
ADB to investigate any violation or potential violation of these undertakings.

C.  Investment Limitations 
(The information in this section is withheld based on exception 9 in paragraph 126 of the PCP.) 
 
D.  Assurances 
29.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (The 
Charter),11 no funding will be disbursed if the Government of the PRC objects to the proposed 
financing to the SCIF.  
 
30.  Following the approval of the proposed investment by the Board of Directors, ADB will 
enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
31.  I am satisfied that the proposed equity investment would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank and recommend that the Board approve the equity 
investment  of  up  to  CNY162.5  million  in  the  Sino-Green  Climate  Investment  Fund  in  the 
People’s  Republic  of  China  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  with  such  terms  and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report and as may be 
reported to the Board.
